Question: Android InputStream.read() horribly slow:I'm working on an Android app that needs to communicate with a server (running on my PC) which is also written by me. The problem is that InputStream.read() takes an eternity, processing 200kb takes something around 30 seconds. My code: client = new Socket("192.168.1.1", 1235);
client.setTcpNoDelay(true);
client.setReceiveBufferSize(1048576);
InputStream is = client.getInputStream();

byte[] buffer = new byte[1048576];
int i = 0;
int length = -1;

while (true)
{
    int b = is.read();
    if (b == -1)
    {
        success = false;
        break;
    }
    buffer[i] = (byte) b;

    if (i == length)
        break;

                                    if (i == 3)
                                    {
                                                length = buffer[0] | buffer[1] << 8 | buffer[2] << 16 | buffer[3] << 24;
                                                    
                                        }

                                        i++;

        }
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: final byte[] lengthBuffer = new byte[3];
try{
    int b = is.read(lengthBuffer);
    // make sure b was 3 and do your length calculation
    final byte buffer = new byte[length];
    b = is.read(buffer);
    // check b and then you have your bytes}
except {System.out.println("Something went wrong.");")}
<<<explanation>>>: Why are you reading each byte individually? It looks like you really want to read the first 3 bytes and figure out your length and then read that block. Then you can at least get the optimizations that Inputstream can provide for reading blocks of data rather than one byte at a time. And you are not allocating that mega array like you currently have.
Question: How to change servlet request body in java filter?: :How can I change request body in java filter to protect from XSS attack?I build HttpServletRequestWrapper and use getparameter for change body butget stream close exception.
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: 
```
public class XSSRequestWrapper extends HttpServletRequestWrapper {
    private byte[] body;

    public XSSRequestWrapper(HttpServletRequest request) throws IOException {
        super(request);
        try (InputStream is = request.getInputStream()) {
            body = new byte[is.available()];
            is.read(body);
        }
    }

    @Override
    public ServletInputStream getInputStream() throws IOException {
        return new ServletInputStream() {
            private int current = 0;

            @Override
            public int read() throws IOException {
                if (current < body.length) {
                    return body[current++];
                } else {
                    return -1;
                }
            }
        };
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads the entire request body into a byte array in the constructor of the wrapper. Then it overrides the getInputStream method to return a ServletInputStream that reads from this byte array. This way, the request body can be read multiple times and the original request body can be protected from XSS attacks.

Question: How to get the current time in milliseconds in Android?:
Answer: <<<api>>>: System.currentTimeMillis()
<<<code>>>: long currentTimeMillis = System.currentTimeMillis();
<<<explanation>>>: The System.currentTimeMillis() function in Java returns the current time in milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00.000 GMT. This is a standard way to get the current time in Android.
